Having a clean and well-written README goes a long way. 

The key is having this structure in place *before* starting. 

It helps cover your bases and promote good habits.‚úÖ

Essay formüëá

https://t.co/oteGpANP3U

7/ 

7‚É£Modeling: Much has happened before we get to modeling, yet this is where people will focus. So, give the people what they want.  

8‚É£Results: Summarize findings and questions answered. You might link to an App, slides or a blog post.

6/

6‚É£Exploratory Analysis (EDA): The purpose is to generate questions that could be answered through inference or prediction. 

After EDA, the project scope could change. 

Describe your rationale here.

5/

5‚É£Getting Data: 

It‚Äôs motivating to build your own dataset, whether through web scraping, accessing an API or other methods. 

This is what makes your project unique. 

Also, data cleaning is important to show.

4/

3‚É£Code, Libraries, and Resources Used: Reproducibility is paramount. Use this space to acknowledge any resources you found helpful.

4‚É£Documenting Progress: Document your daily decisions and rationale. Future you will be grateful.

3/

1‚É£Motivation: Describe the project, motivation and the question(s) you're answering.

2‚É£Initial Scope: Like any creative endeavor, the project could veer in unanticipated directions. 

Give yourself permission to follow new leads as the project unfolds.

2/

A well documented README is your compass üß≠. 

When in the weeds of a project, a well-structured README  is your clarity.

Here is a structure for your next #datascience project:

1/ 

In my first software project, 'documentation' was an after-thought. 

Seen as inconsequential work.

‚ùåBig mistake.

I hate paper work.üñáÔ∏è

At first glance "documentation" sounds like paper work.

But for a #datascience project, "documentation" is a precursor to "impact".

If it's not documented, did it happen?üëáüßµ

You'll likely connect tables more often than run experiments. 

That's the role of creativity in data science.

#rstats #python

From simple correlations to the complex deep learning algorithms. 

Data from different sources must be connected.  

For aspiring data scientists, the implications are clear. 

Learn to connect tables (SQL) and data frames (#dplyr, #pandas).

Every time someone requests "insights" from "data", they are really asking is to connect different data sources. 

Literally, connect. 

We're joining data. 

We‚Äôre merging data. 

We're just connecting things.

"Creativity is just connecting things."

True to his word, what is the iPhone if not connecting three separate devices?

An iPod.

A Phone.

An Internet Communicator.

I can vividly recall Jobs cadence as he repeated these words shortly before literally putting a dent in the universe. https://t.co/ocL7outeQN

What is the role of creativity in #DataScience ?

Unpopular opinion: Data science is more creative than scientific üëáüßµ

Essay form: 

https://t.co/i75TKG2uQY

7/

Don't worry about starting with the right language or having the right reasons to start. 

Getting started is more important than having the perfect start.

6/

General-purpose languages give you generalizable skills.

5/

When I transitioned from web dev to data analytics, I worried all the time learning JavaScript would go to waste. 

Those fears were unfounded. 

It actually helped me learn #Rstats and #Python

4/ 

Setting aside syntax differences, object-oriented in #javascript is object-oriented in #Python 

You can create classes and instances of classes with their own methods and properties.

3/

While focusing on "the problem you're trying to solve" is sensible advice, it may not be for everyone.

But worry not, programming knowledge is transferable.

2/ 

I can sympathize with people who aren‚Äôt clear about their motivations because I wasn‚Äôt when starting out. 

I liked the "idea" of coding more than I had a legitimate itch to scratch.

It's not the ideal reason to start, but that's where I was.

1/

The sensible advice is to focus on the problem you're trying to solve. 

When this is clear, the answer reveals itself.

[New Programmer]: 

- What language should I learn first? 
- What framework? 
- What do employers want?

[The Internet]: 

- Here are 64,359 influencers under the age of 10 and their hot takes. 

What to do? üëá #CodeNewbie

Finally, we have the "Category of 1" newsletters so unique, they occupy their own category (at least for now):

9/ 

Unlike Curation, the Educationüßë‚Äçüéì category focuses less on current events and aims to guide readers through a course of study.

Then there‚Äôs industry pace. 

Slow industries like those that dominated last century (e.g., Metal‚öíÔ∏è, Petroleum üõ¢Ô∏è, Manufacturing ‚öôÔ∏è) can be more specialized.

When product and market are influx, fast communicationüó£Ô∏è and iteration cycles ‚ôªÔ∏è are needed.

The more a crypto network is worth, the more expensive it is to attack.

Another reason to celebrate price gains.

https://t.co/x0CAi9Xq6a

5/ 

In fact, the data provided by https://t.co/6vtCQdwfD1 suggests a near perfect correlation between Market Capitalization and Cost to Attack, at r = 0.94. https://t.co/p8Cb2MPPQu

4/

And when price increases, the costs of buying new equipment goes up, which makes it difficult for any one entity to accumulate too much hash power. 

As a result, the entire network is more secure.

3/

More hardware and hash power allow a node to secretly mine a side chain, which they can later ‚Äúfool‚Äù the rest of the network into accepting.

2/ 

Node(s) with more than 51% of the network hashing power can pull shenanigans, such as double-spending. 

üí∞ ‚û°Ô∏è üí∞üí∞

1/

Bitcoin's big innovation was making digital transaction difficult to replicate. 

Nodes follow the longest chain as the "correct" chain.

All time high.üìà

There are no sweeter words for an investor. 

For public crypto networks #Bitcoin #Ethereum , there's a *different* reason to celebrate üëáüßµ

Creating visualizations, much like writing, is an iterative process. These  5‚É£concepts can be lurking in your data. 

You might combine one or more before your message and visuals align.

7/

Geospatial: Maps

6/ 

Relationships: Between two or more variables

5/ 

Distributions: For continuous variables

https://t.co/DnmWwxeoXQ

4/ 

Proportions: Comparing amounts (ie., side-by-side bar) or showing parts of whole (ie., pie chart).
